Award.AwardTitle: Manufacture of Strong, Tough Hybrid Hydrogels

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding for the manufacture of hybrid hydrogels, wherein physical and cross-linked networks are incorporated into a single multi-component polymer. Hydrogels are three-dimensional networks composed of chemically and/or physically-crosslinked hydrophilic polymers that have applications in diverse technologies such as drug or agrochemical delivery, food and personal care products, optics, fluidics, wound healing and tissue engineering. Chemical hydrogels formed from covalent bonds have permanent shapes, but they generally exhibit poor mechanical strength and toughness, while physical hydrogels exhibit good toughness, but lack the creep resistance of covalent gels. The research includes the synthesis of hybrid hydrogels and the characterization of the microstructure, swelling behavior, flow and viscoelastic properties and mechanical properties of neutral and charged materials. The objectives are to develop strong, tough hydrogels, understand the mechanism of toughening in hybrid hydrogels and the development of manufacturing methods for producing shaped gel objects by solvent or melt injection, melt shaping and electrospinning of nanofibers.

The results of this research will lead to improvements in the mechanical properties and manufacturing methods for producing hydrogel products. The development of an understanding of the mechanism by which strong, tough materials that are mostly water (i.e., hydrogels) are achieved will lead to the design of improved soft materials for existing applications and expand the application of hydrogels into technologies for which they are currently unsuitable, because of poor stiffness, strength and/or fracture toughness. In addition to the expansion of commercial applications of hydrogels, the substitution of hydrogels for many existing material applications should also have positive environmental implications, in that most hydrogels are environmentally benign. The nano-structured morphology expected for hybrid hydrogels may also lead to smart applications of these materials, such as shape memory and/or self-healing behavior.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The objective of this project was to understand the properties and structure of supramolecular hydrogels formed by random copolymerization of an alkyl acrylamide (AA) and a fluoracrylate (FA), the latter being used at a concentration of 2 - 22 mol%. The AA component is water soluble and the FA component is water insoluble and immiscible with the predominantly poly(AA) chains.  As a result, the FA moieties phase separate into ~6 nm hydrophobic nanodomains . that produce a physically crosslinked network. Thus, when swollen with water, the material becomes a hydrogel. These hydrogels exhibit high modulus (103 - 106 Pa) and extremely high fracture toughness (103 - 104 J/m3, which is comparable or exceeds that of cartilage. The origin of the toughness is the reversible supramolecular crosslinks formed by hydrophobic interactions of the  fluroalkyl chains of the copolymer.

In addition to characterizing the copolymer structure that is responsible for the excellent hydrogel properties of these hydrogels, some specific applications were investigated:

The nanophase-separated hydrophilic/hydrophobic random copolymer hydrogels partially or completely inhibited ice formation to temperatures as low as -70°C.  The ability to prevent water from freezing was due to the ~10 nm spacing of the phase separated hydrophobic nanodomains, which provided a microstructure similar to that of anti-freeze proteins. The distance between the nanodomains controlled how much the gel suppressed ice formation and the distance between nanodomains was controlled by the composition of the copolymer.  The ability of these hydrogels, which contain 50 - 80 wt% water, to suppress/inhibit ice formation may have biomedical applications, especially with regard to cell encapsulation and storage where freeze-thaw cycles may occur, as well as other applications where ice prevention is desirable, e.g., de-icing surfaces and preventing crops from freezing.

Hybrid hydrogels prepared  by covalently crosslinking copolymers of N,N-dimethylacrylamide (DMA), 2-(N-ethylperfluoro-octanesulfonamido) ethyl methacrylate (FOSM), hydroxyethyl acrylate and 2-cinnamoyloxyethyl acrylate and containing ~60-70% water exhibited shape memory behavior.  The hybrid hydrogels, were relatively soft and elastic and exhibited high mechanical strength, extensibility and fracture toughness.  The covalent crosslinks formed a permanent network that provided a permanent shape for the gel. A second, temporary was derived from the glassy nanodomains due to microphase separation of the hydrophobic FOSM species. The switching temperature  for shape memory was the glass transition temperature of the nanodomains, ~45°C.  Some creep relaxation occurred in the fixed shape due to viscoelastic effects of the supramolecular crosslinks, but shape fixing efficiencies of 84 – 88% were achieved for the temporary shape after 24 h at 10°C.  Shape recovery to the permanent shape was achieved by reheating the hydrogel to 65°C and was essentially quantitative.

Tough stretchable AA/FA copolymer hydrogel fiber mats were prepared by electrospinning the copolymer in a isopropanol/water mixed solvent. The mats exhibited excellent mechanical properties and were stretchable to more than 200% strain. The modulus of the hydrogel fiber mat was similar to that of a compression molded bulk hydrogel, but the ultimate stress and strain for the fiber mats were much greater than that for the bulk analogous hydrogel -- even though the mats contained >25% more water. The fracture toughness of fiber mats was 70% higher that of the bulk hydrogel, which was a consequence of a more uniform nanodomain structure produced during the electrospinning process. These hydrogel mats may be useful for a variety  biomedical applications due to their ease of fabrication, lack of residual monomer, high porosity, excellent mechanical properties and the anti-freeze property described above.

In addition to the research on tough supramolecular copolymer hydrogels, we also studied tough double-network (DN) hydrogels, which have dominated the research effort in the field of tough hydrogel. An important finding was that these are not interpenetrating networks as commonly though, but in fact the two networks are connected by covalent bonds developed during the polymerization of the second network in the presence of residual unsaturation that always occurs in the free radical polymerization of vinyl monomers.  The connectivity of the two networks in a conventional DN hydrogel is essential  for developing  toughness, which has heretofore not been appreciated. Other work concentrated on the mechanics of DN hydrogels and the mechanism for developing toughness, which is essentially the fracture of a brittle first network, which can be a neutral polymer, as well as a polyelectrolyte.

 

Broader Impacts

8 PhD students, 1 MS students and 1 REU student and 1 RET scientist worked on this project and received training in the general field of polymer science and engineering and in the specific sub-fields of rheology, associating polymers and stimuli-responsive materials.. The project produced 9 published journal articles, 4 other journal manuscripts currently under review, 17 conference talks/proceedings and 1 patent.  Also, 2 PhD dissertations and 1 MS thesis.

 


Last Modified: 07/08/2017
Modified by: Robert A Weiss
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Intellectual Merit The objective of this project was to understand the properties and structure of supramolecular hydrogels formed by random copolymerization of an alkyl acrylamide (AA) and a fluoracrylate (FA), the latter being used at a concentration of 2 - 22 mol%. The AA component is water soluble and the FA component is water insoluble and immiscible with the predominantly poly(AA) chains. As a result, the FA moieties phase separate into ~6 nm hydrophobic nanodomains . that produce a physically crosslinked network. Thus, when swollen with water, the material becomes a hydrogel. These hydrogels exhibit high modulus (103 - 106 Pa) and extremely high fracture toughness (103 - 104 J/m3, which is comparable or exceeds that of cartilage. In addition to characterizing the copolymer structure that is responsible for the excellent hydrogel properties of these hydrogels, some specific applications were investigated: The nanophase-separated hydrophilic/hydrophobic random copolymer hydrogels partially or completely inhibited ice formation to temperatures as low as -70°C. The ability to prevent water from freezing was due to the ~10 nm spacing of the phase separated hydrophobic nanodomains, which provided a microstructure similar to that of anti-freeze proteins. The distance between the nanodomains controlled how much the gel suppressed ice formation and the distance between nanodomains was controlled by the composition of the copolymer. These hydrogel mats may be useful for a variety biomedical applications due to their ease of fabrication, lack of residual monomer, high porosity, excellent mechanical properties and the anti-freeze property described above. In addition to the research on tough supramolecular copolymer hydrogels, we also studied tough double-network (DN) hydrogels, which have dominated the research effort in the field of tough hydrogel. An important finding was that these are not interpenetrating networks as commonly though, but in fact the two networks are connected by covalent bonds developed during the polymerization of the second network in the presence of residual unsaturation that always occurs in the free radical polymerization of vinyl monomers. The connectivity of the two networks in a conventional DN hydrogel is essential for developing toughness, which has heretofore not been appreciated. Other work concentrated on the mechanics of DN hydrogels and the mechanism for developing toughness, which is essentially the fracture of a brittle first network, which can be a neutral polymer, as well as a polyelectrolyte. The project produced 9 published journal articles, 4 other journal manuscripts currently under review, 17 conference talks/proceedings and 1 patent. Also, 2 PhD dissertations and 1 MS thesis.
